Responses.Other Web API Issues: signing up for a simple api becoming too hard.   i've found great apis that have been taken down after being acquired or shut down.

Responses.Other Web API Issues: api endpoints exposing sensitive/privacy information, api services requiring authorisation but not enforce it, services returning wrong data (e.g. call /user but receive product details), incorrect authorization implementation, ...
Responses.Expectations: expect failure and develop fail-first systems with retry possibilities. consider any system beyond your control as unstable piece of crap so you are prepared for service unavailability. if it works, you're just lucky.

Important Features of Web APIs: Support (e.g., API client wrappers or sample codes) for familiar programming languages
Responses.Expectations:
api should be designed for the consumers (client/developers) (rarely done, often made to match the internal requirements)
api should be well documented (rarely done, it's time and money)
api should be maintained (rarely done, no time and money)

to me, what's most important is that web api documentation is high quality, and that any known or reported issues get resolved fairly quickly. it's not viable not to have any problems, but if they're resolved rapidly, then it's a good experience. i consider github api v3 (https://developer.github.com/v3/) to be a gold standard for web apis. it has high quality documentation, simple and easy to use endpoints. i wish other apis were as good.

Important Features of Web APIs: Support (e.g., API client wrappers or sample codes) for familiar programming languages
Relatively high popularity (e.g., the number of followers and popularity score)

Responses.Expectations:
i expect to find up to date and complete docs in the first place, even if i'm developing the api i like to have access to docs for when i have to code the frontend for that api - using swagger is more than enough imho as long as devs remember to include all the basics like mandatory headers, auth mechanisms and summaries for all endpoints.

something else i find it hard to live without is unit testing. throughout my career i've been part of many projects but so far none of them have implemented unit testing and for that i've had to suffer from unnecessary added difficulty when tracking bugs. i think standardizing something as simple as unit testing will boost the overall quality of apis (in this case this refers to lack of bugs) and development experience at the same time.

then, i expect us devs to look at the products we build through the eyes of our users. what i mean is: after we finish developing a feature we should test it out and everything we do that we think is cumbersome we should make it more convenient because that's what our users would want. an example of this would be expecting the user to pass an id that is not easily retrievable to access a certain resource when we could easily identify those by some other, more representative field.

really hope this helps!
